4f1bb69c-9330-4ec7-818c-e88abf0d2153.description: The course covers a broad survey of American history from New World exploration and settlement through the Civil War. Topics include American origins and early development; colonial religion, economics, diversity, opportunity and oppression; the American Revolution; the Republican Experiment; the violence of party politics; Nationalism and White Mens Democracy; race, gender, and class in the Old South; Age of Expansion; the Sectional Crisis; secession and the Civil War; and Reconstruction.
4f1bb69c-9330-4ec7-818c-e88abf0d2153.name: American History I

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

6e40539b-4ea7-4e0c-b6b9-5db55babf634.description: The course introduces students to management philosophies in today's changing world. It includes globalization, ethics, diversity, customer service, and innovation from a managerial perspective. Topics include social responsibility and managerial ethics; decision making; strategic management and planning; organizational structure and communications; human resource management; motivating and leading others; controlling organizational performance; and operations management.
6e40539b-4ea7-4e0c-b6b9-5db55babf634.name: Principles of Management

alignments.name: Regional Accrediation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

23b33665-704f-4e18-904f-4df6e7c5afbe.description: The course objective is to develop written communication skills with an emphasis on understanding the writing process, analyzing readings, and practicing writing for personal and professional applications. The general course topics include paragraphs; critical thinking skills; college writing; essays; writing a summary; research writing; writing in the disciplines; clarity and style; description and narration; classification; and comparison and contrast.
23b33665-704f-4e18-904f-4df6e7c5afbe.name: English Composition I

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examination, and written papers with a minimum passing score is 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

38e4b38e-6821-4045-84a9-01c6ee64498a.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the fundamentals of American government and politics focusing on the historical evolution of government and policies, the major institutions, and the major processes. Course goals include developing an interest in and understanding of today's government, policy development, and politics as well as developing critical thinking and information-literacy skills in the areas of government and politics.
38e4b38e-6821-4045-84a9-01c6ee64498a.name: American Government

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

968908ce-8493-437d-9166-f2bbc61baca0.description: The course objective is to cover a broad survey of American history from 1865 through the New Millennium. The general course topics include the West; industrial society; urban society and political realignments; Empire and the Progressive Era; Age of Progressivism; the nation at war; modern America; World War II and the Cold War; the 1960s; a crisis in confidence, 1969-1980; the Republican Resurgence, 1980-1992; and the end of the American century.
968908ce-8493-437d-9166-f2bbc61baca0.name: American History II

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audiovisual materials and computer based training.

e44a7727-c13c-44f0-867e-f8f0a357cda2.description: The course explores sociological processes that underlie everyday life, focusing on globalization, cultural diversity, critical thinking, new technology and the growing influence of mass media. Topics include sociology; culture; socialization; deviance and social control; global stratification and racial discrimination; gender and age; social class and decision making; politics and economics; marriage and family; education and religion; population and urbanization; and social change.
e44a7727-c13c-44f0-867e-f8f0a357cda2.name: Introduction to Sociology

alignments.name: Regional Accredidation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, examination, and presentations with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials, computer based training, and practical exercises.

13cccf5c-9bf3-4bef-a979-60b148667c58.description: The course objective is to introduce human behavior. It includes the study of the theories and concepts of psychology including the scope of psychology; biological foundations and the brain; sensation; perception; motivation; personality; learning and memory; emotion; states of consciousness; personality theories; cognition; life-span development; and applied psychology.
13cccf5c-9bf3-4bef-a979-60b148667c58.name: Introduction to Psychology

alignments.name: Regional Accrediation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examination, and written papers with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

a7652f59-bf79-44c3-bea5-3567e0d6006f.description: The course objective is to provide students with a view of the principle areas of marketing. It explores the factors influencing how marketing decisions are made, including the impact of marketing decisions on an organization and its customers. Students gain a working knowledge of practical marketing and business vocabulary. Additionally, students analyze today's global, highly competitive marketplace and evaluate how the actions of competitors' influence marketing decisions.
a7652f59-bf79-44c3-bea5-3567e0d6006f.name: Principles of Marketing

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual and computer based training.

c1b6dbef-b9fd-4c63-b354-8969a31d4471.description: The course objective is to serve as an introductory study of the principles of oral communication as transactional and adaptive interaction. Foundational elements of communication theory and practice will be emphasized. Particular attention will be placed on the development of preparatory, organizational, and presentational skills necessary for effective informative and persuasive presentations.
c1b6dbef-b9fd-4c63-b354-8969a31d4471.name: Essentials of Speech

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, performance rubrics, and presentations with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials, learner presentations and lecture.

a3f21c8b-c5fc-43ac-9650-b8adb0a818a6.description: The course objective is to introduce foundational concepts of economic principles, such as opportunity costs, supply, and demand. However, the course focus is to explore primary macroeconomic principles, including measurement, real economy in the long run, money economy in the long run, macroeconomic fluctuations, and policy issues. Students will be presented with real world contemporary examples that apply theory to practice, demonstrating the relevance of macroeconomic thought.
a3f21c8b-c5fc-43ac-9650-b8adb0a818a6.name: Macroeconomics

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

6eb75fa0-9e29-4eb6-ae00-140ee4c13d60.description: The course objective is to present a variety of topics essential to a student's development in critical thinking. Students are introduced to concepts essential to the comprehension, analysis, and creation of arguments: induction, deduction, and informal fallacies, Aristotelian and symbolic logic, modes of persuasion, perspective and bias, language and meaning, culminating in the development of reasonable strategies for belief formation.
6eb75fa0-9e29-4eb6-ae00-140ee4c13d60.name: Critical Thinking

The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

f2812edd-341d-4ffb-84ba-92b00e4081e8.description: Students develop a logical, conceptual, and analytical understanding of microeconomic principles. This course introduces foundational economic principles, such as opportunity costs and supply and demand, and explores primary microeconomic principles, including efficiency and fairness in markets, government actions and their impacts, the decisions that consumers and producers make, different market structures from perfect competition to monopoly, and factor markets and income distribution.
f2812edd-341d-4ffb-84ba-92b00e4081e8.name: Microeconomics

The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

242fb991-f261-4984-a64b-e5e996e62d61.description: The course objective is to offer students the skills necessary to interpret and critically evaluate statistics commonly used to describe, predict, and evaluate data in an information driven environment. The focus is on the conceptual understanding of how statistics can be used and how to evaluate statistical data.
242fb991-f261-4984-a64b-e5e996e62d61.name: Statistics

alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

36d9c221-222d-4f20-8fc3-c07fcd987a64.description: The course objective is to build on lessons learned in English Composition I. In addition to reviewing the writing process, students learn research techniques, citation techniques, documentation formats, and critical analysis of written topics.
36d9c221-222d-4f20-8fc3-c07fcd987a64.name: English Composition II

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

8e54a7cc-1b53-4ec7-82d5-d495dcace762.description: The course provides students with an overview of business in a global society serving as an introduction to business terminology, concepts, environments, systems, strategies, and current issues. Topics include the business ethics and social responsibility; new ventures; business enterprise; managing employees; marketing; product pricing, distribution, and promotion; productivity and quality; information systems; communication; accounting; banking and finance; and risk management.
8e54a7cc-1b53-4ec7-82d5-d495dcace762.name: Introduction to Business

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation

84f1a6f7-354e-4b04-80d1-37ce55c086d7.description: The course objective is to present the elements and examples of three genres of literature: fiction, poetry, and drama. Students will learn the origins of literature and the purposes of the study of literature. Students will associate the study of literature and thinking skills, such as critical reading. Students will utilize thinking skills to research and apply literary criticism to analyze and critique various literary works in the context of discussing and writing about literature.
84f1a6f7-354e-4b04-80d1-37ce55c086d7.name: Introduction to Literature

7346804c-2fdf-4e3f-9ec7-3bb05d47e626.description: The course objective is to present several ethical theories and explores contextual issues. Students are asked to examine ethical theories; moral assumptions and moral principles; apply ethical theories to moral problems; construct a moral system utilizing a theoretical framework; and apply the system to contemporary moral issues.
7346804c-2fdf-4e3f-9ec7-3bb05d47e626.name: Ethics

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

6abfacd1-8bac-4720-be66-fcb08ebad072.description: The course objective is to explore the relationship between man and the environment. Students examine the balance between natural resources and the needs of mankind. Students explore the scientific, political, economic, and social implications of environmental science.
6abfacd1-8bac-4720-be66-fcb08ebad072.name: Environmental Science

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

59caaa7e-2b90-41fe-8311-b73a56d4a086.description: The course objective is to cover a broad survey of key concepts of college algebra. Students will be introduced to solving equations and inequalities; functions, including linear, quadratic, polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic; systems of equations and inequalities; and series and sequences.
59caaa7e-2b90-41fe-8311-b73a56d4a086.name: College Algebra

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based learning.

05ebb12e-b820-492a-ab23-c883c6cb2204.description: The course objective is to focus on Human Resource (HR) management skills used by business managers in day-to-day operations. While focusing on the different aspects of HR management and practices, problem solving, and critical thinking skills are applied. The general course topics include an introduction to environmental science; overview of Human Resource (HR) management; training and development; employee compensation and benefits; employee relations; and global HR management.
05ebb12e-b820-492a-ab23-c883c6cb2204.name: Human Resource Management

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.

e3185bde-486d-4969-ab75-8a3fe716d2ab.description: The course presents the key areas of biology at an introductory post-secondary level for non-majors. Students are introduced to the chemistry of life, cellular biology, molecular biology, genetics, evolution, and ecology. Topics include basic component of life: the cell; energy and membrane transport in cells; cellular reproduction; DNA: the molecule of life; patterns of inheritance; evolution; biodiversity; ecology; population and community ecology; biotechnology.
e3185bde-486d-4969-ab75-8a3fe716d2ab.name: Introduction to Biology

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual and computer based training.

7dfe71b9-852d-447c-8eee-3bb59af14379.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the criminal justice system and its three main components: law enforcement, the courts, and corrections. It reviews what constitutes a criminal offense, how crime is measured, and theories of crime causation. This course also looks at issues and challenges facing today's criminal justice system and examines possible future directions.
7dfe71b9-852d-447c-8eee-3bb59af14379.name: Introduction to Criminal Justice

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is computer based training.

a55485d3-c5b4-4c40-a90a-9cf58497bf29.description: The course examines organizational theory and application. It provides a comprehensive review of individual, group, and organizational performance in relation to organizational structures in contemporary business settings. Topics include organizational behavior; self and others; decision making; motivation; emotions and moods; groups and teams; leadership and power; conflict and negotiation; organizational structure; organizational culture; human resources; and change and stress management.
a55485d3-c5b4-4c40-a90a-9cf58497bf29.name: Organizational Behavior

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

23faa7d9-cf42-41c8-9d1b-6d50c47ef31b.description: The course covers a broad survey of business law with respect to torts, crimes, intellectual property, contracts, negotiable instruments, agency, employment, and forms of business organization. Students explore the relationship between business and the law with respect to ethics and social responsibility, government regulation, property, and international trade. Students gain a working knowledge of practical rules of law as well as legal solutions for business- related issues.
23faa7d9-cf42-41c8-9d1b-6d50c47ef31b.name: Business Law

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

aebf0d67-dada-4856-ab4e-388d4051f1c9.description: The course objective is to provide students with the information and skills they need to succeed in their studies, including setting academic goals; managing time and financial resources to meet those goals and developing an awareness of how they learn; build thinking, listening, reading, studying, note-taking, test-taking, and information literacy skills; have discussions on stress management and career development; and apply critical thinking skills to solve problems and evaluate situations.
aebf0d67-dada-4856-ab4e-388d4051f1c9.name: Student Success

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: Methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, and examinations with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.

This is a distance-delivered course. Methods of instruction include audio visual materials, practical exercises, discussion, learner presentations, and computer-based training. General course topics include online learning; self knowledge; SMART goals; online life balance; online collaboration and teamwork; types of online classrooms; online communication; reading; writing; studying; online critical thinking; constructive feedback; computer concerns; and online success today and tomorrow.

f897bced-6fbc-491e-aef7-74adf001cb02.description: The course objective is to provide an introduction to business accounting. Topics include accounting concepts and principles; financial statements; internal control design; accounting and the business environment; recording business transactions; the adjusting process; completing the accounting cycle; merchandising operations; merchandise inventory; accounting information systems; receivables; plant assets and intangibles; current liabilities and payroll; and partnership.
f897bced-6fbc-491e-aef7-74adf001cb02.name: Accounting I

7ef45532-1f7d-47f4-ad16-b98f310af137.description: The course objective is to provide students with a foundational knowledge of financial management. The course covers key language and terminology; time-value of money; financial markets and securities; financial statements; financial analysis; risk and return; valuation of stocks and bonds; capital budgeting and valuation; cost of capital and capital structure; working capital management; dividend policy; and international finance.
7ef45532-1f7d-47f4-ad16-b98f310af137.name: Introduction to Finance

Topics include corporate accounting and financial statements; long-term liabilities; cash flow and financial statement analysis; managerial accounting; budgeting; and using financial data to make business decisions.
8bf037a4-36b8-42b1-8e7b-e4965a48bd04.name: Accounting II

4582b2d5-d673-4620-a890-23c9c9331e31.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the challenges and opportunities of entrepreneurship. It includes sound academic theory, success stories, case studies, and exercises in critical thinking to help students develop the understanding, skills, and plans needed to start a successful new business.
4582b2d5-d673-4620-a890-23c9c9331e31.name: Entrepreneurship

5a841696-387e-42a6-a4e7-b9b578f92450.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the study of crime and criminal behavior as well as to theories of crime causation. It reviews different types of crime and examines crime control policy. Topics include patterns of crime; theories of criminology; biological & psychological theories of criminal behavior; social structure and process; social development and conflict; crimes against perssons & property; drug abuse and crime; other types of crime; and social policy and the future.
5a841696-387e-42a6-a4e7-b9b578f92450.name: Criminology

a260fd35-1ce4-475d-9b49-e6163504925e.description: The course objective is to provide an introduction for undergraduate business students to information systems (IS). The course includes important topics related to IS, such as the drivers of IS, database concepts, IS development, and the types of systems used in organizations.
a260fd35-1ce4-475d-9b49-e6163504925e.name: Introduction to Business Information Systems

2f17bb20-6100-439d-a098-8a08683ef528.description: The course objective is to cover an overview of the anatomical structures and physiology of the human body. The course discusses each body system in terms of the major anatomical structures and functions and explains how each system participates in homeostasis of the body. In addition, the course discusses selected major pathologies, common issues and changes that occur in each body system throughout the lifespan.
2f17bb20-6100-439d-a098-8a08683ef528.name: Anatomy & Physiology

8292cd9e-5401-46a8-973f-c6723fd56b10.description: The course objective is to enhance your personal and professional learning agenda and welcome the challenges of supervision. In this course, you will learn about the roles and responsibilities of supervisors. The course builds from a foundation of fundamental skills through a pyramid of understanding the expanded scope of responsibilities for first-time, first-line supervisors through the chairman of the board in private, service, or public organizations.
8292cd9e-5401-46a8-973f-c6723fd56b10.name: Supervision

The course is focused on skills such as effectiveness in small groups, listening skills, negotiation, giving and receiving feedback, intercultural awareness, digital etiquette, and effective presentations. The course is focused not just on what a student learns but on what he or she can do with what they have learned. This course is structure
2a2508a4-107e-4b1c-aaf0-36f2b00f0c44.name: Interpersonal Communication

56979711-2e48-4022-9066-ffbfcbfafeba.description: The course examines the causes of victimization and looks at theories associated with violent victimization. It analyzes the offender-victim relationship and presents ideas on preventing violence and responding to victimization proactively and reactively. Topics include child and elder abuse; domestic violence, stalking, and sexual violence; workplace violence & harassment; employer liability; school violence; criminal injustice; legislation and correctional facilities; and terrorism.
56979711-2e48-4022-9066-ffbfcbfafeba.name: Victimology

74cdeeec-dd02-4f09-8c50-fbeee47d9100.description: The course objective is to provide a basic math review; business statistics; profit calculations; payroll; banking; insurance; taxes; and other business topics including whole numbers, fractions and decimals; percentages and statistics; trade and cash discounts, markup, and markdown; interest, discount, credit, and value; annuities, sinking funds, stocks, and bonds; mortgages; depreciation; inventory financial statements.
74cdeeec-dd02-4f09-8c50-fbeee47d9100.name: Business Math

alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

The methods of instruction include audio visual materials, computer based training, and practical exercises.

52b8fbf0-1998-4764-91f4-be294c95b2f7.description: The course objective is to provide an introduction for undergraduate business students to information systems (IS). The course includes important topics related to IS, such as the drivers of IS, database concepts, IS development, and the types of systems used in organizations.
52b8fbf0-1998-4764-91f4-be294c95b2f7.name: Introduction to Business Information Systems (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based learning.

72c42341-3c51-465f-9900-dd1c9c0ba0d4.description: The course objective is to present a variety of topics essential to a student's development in critical thinking. Students are introduced to concepts essential to the comprehension, analysis, and creation of arguments: induction, deduction, and informal fallacies, Aristotelian and symbolic logic, modes of persuasion, perspective and bias, language and meaning, culminating in the development of reasonable strategies for belief formation.
72c42341-3c51-465f-9900-dd1c9c0ba0d4.name: Critical Thinking (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

f0c5310f-fa6b-46f9-8efc-7bf818050ffb.description: The course objective is to teach students the fundamentals of criminal investigation by examining the processes involved in identifying and arresting criminal suspects, identifying the types of crimes and offenses, and preparing for court. Topics include crime scene and crime lab; intelligence and surveillance; search and seizure and making the arrest; interviews, interrogations, and informants; multiple types of offenses; and preparation for court.
f0c5310f-fa6b-46f9-8efc-7bf818050ffb.name: Criminal Investigation

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

56f53567-fd4b-41ef-9303-2b531ef74c70.description: This course provides a comprehensive survey of the physical, cognitive, and socioemotional changes that occur throughout a lifetime. Students analyze human growth through each of the major stages of development using key theories and the lifespan perspective. Topics include prenatal development, childhood, adulthood, and death and dying.
56f53567-fd4b-41ef-9303-2b531ef74c70.name: Lifespan Development

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

2f72a68c-ba73-4a5d-a9e7-0f173aee9721.description: The course objective is to look at the ethical dilemmas and professional problems faced by criminal justice personnel. Students review various ethical perspectives and discuss the practical applicability of ethical ideals. Topics include recognizing ethical decisions; virtue ethics; formalism; utilitarianism; crime and law; ethical theories, crime, and law; courts adjudication; punishment and corrections; liability; and being ethical when no one is looking.
2f72a68c-ba73-4a5d-a9e7-0f173aee9721.name: Criminal Justice Ethics

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

69ab3319-b46d-4471-b101-f74cc350890a.description: The course examines organizational theory and application. It provides a comprehensive review of individual, group, and organizational performance in relation to organizational structures in contemporary business settings. Topics include organizational behavior; self and others; decision making; motivation; emotions and moods; groups and teams; leadership and power; conflict and negotiation; organizational structure; organizational culture; human resources; and change and stress management.
69ab3319-b46d-4471-b101-f74cc350890a.name: Organizational Behavior (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

c1480150-174b-47d9-9baf-971e821407e4.description: The course objective is to cover medical terminology, symbols and abbreviations, and the application of this new language in the field of health care. While terms are covered as they relate to body structure and function, the main focus is on medical vocabulary and being able to construct terms using word parts such as roots, suffixes, and prefixes.
c1480150-174b-47d9-9baf-971e821407e4.name: Medical Terminology (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

c8952e96-8188-464c-a895-30b27e78b1a0.description: The course objective is to present several ethical theories and explores contextual issues. Students are asked to examine ethical theories; moral assumptions and moral principles; apply ethical theories to moral problems; construct a moral system utilizing a theoretical framework; and apply the system to contemporary moral issues.
c8952e96-8188-464c-a895-30b27e78b1a0.name: Ethics (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

d72ba31b-c357-45dc-9c38-7ee71c060bcf.description: This course provides an understanding of various statistical methods and predictive analytics that can be applied to real-life situations. Students focus on the process of performing a statistical study: collecting the appropriate data, summarizing the data, analyzing that data, and then making conclusions about the data collected based on the results of the analysis. This course focuses on inferential statistics and using tools, such as graphs, and calculating population parameters.
d72ba31b-c357-45dc-9c38-7ee71c060bcf.name: Concepts in Statistics

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

7afa00fa-5f5e-4e2a-b912-d43affbcdaa8.description: The course objective is to provide students with an overview of the criminal justice system and its processes. It examines the courtroom work group, the trial process, challenges to the process, and the juvenile court system. Topics include introduction to the courts; crimes and defenses; history of the courts; prosecution and defense; judges; jurors and other participants; case attrition and bail; plea bargains; jury trials; court-ordered punishment; sentencing; and appeals and juvenile courts.
7afa00fa-5f5e-4e2a-b912-d43affbcdaa8.name: Criminal Courts

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

37f63499-9dd4-4a2f-8fb7-4d8a1436d360.description: The course objective is to present the elements and examples of three genres of literature: fiction, poetry, and drama. Students will learn the origins of literature and the purposes of the study of literature. Students will associate the study of literature and thinking skills, such as critical reading. Students will utilize thinking skills to research and apply literary criticism to analyze and critique various literary works in the context of discussing and writing about literature.
37f63499-9dd4-4a2f-8fb7-4d8a1436d360.name: Introduction to Literature (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

b92e89a5-580a-42ec-9406-89ad74776002.description: The course objective is to cover a broad survey of key concepts of college algebra. Students will be introduced to solving equations and inequalities; functions, including linear, quadratic, polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic; systems of equations and inequalities; and series and sequences.
b92e89a5-580a-42ec-9406-89ad74776002.name: College Algebra (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based learning.

69a3ce7c-57ec-4a3c-8c86-3ad6f40f75ef.description: The course objective is to develop written communication skills with an emphasis on understanding the writing process, analyzing readings, and practicing writing for personal and professional applications. The general course topics include paragraphs; critical thinking skills; college writing; essays; writing a summary; research writing; writing in the disciplines; clarity and style; description and narration; classification; and comparison and contrast.
69a3ce7c-57ec-4a3c-8c86-3ad6f40f75ef.name: English Composition I (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examination, and written papers with a minimum passing score is 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

8e8859b6-6129-40e4-bcaf-6b481669eb8b.description: The course objective is for students to develop a logical, conceptual, and analytical understanding of economic principles and to deal with problems associated with the allocation of resources; decisions made by consumers; production by firms; pricing in various market conditions; government actions in markets; measuring aggregate output; economic growth; employment and unemployment; money and banking; and fiscal and monetary policies intended to achieve economic goals.
8e8859b6-6129-40e4-bcaf-6b481669eb8b.name: Introduction to Economics (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

c6405195-f845-4ef4-84da-f7b0cf829d98.description: The course objective is to offer students the skills necessary to interpret and critically evaluate statistics commonly used to describe, predict, and evaluate data in an information driven environment. The focus is on the conceptual understanding of how statistics can be used and how to evaluate statistical data.
c6405195-f845-4ef4-84da-f7b0cf829d98.name: Statistics (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

3c95d541-bede-483c-9765-febb11555ca2.description: The course covers a broad survey of American history from New World exploration and settlement through the Civil War. Topics include American origins and early development; colonial religion, economics, diversity, opportunity and oppression; the American Revolution; the Republican Experiment; the violence of party politics; Nationalism and White Mens Democracy; race, gender, and class in the Old South; Age of Expansion; the Sectional Crisis; secession and the Civil War; and Reconstruction.
3c95d541-bede-483c-9765-febb11555ca2.name: American History I (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

297f6c08-f722-432c-94fb-ecee49854016.description: The course objective is to introduce human behavior. It includes the study of the theories and concepts of psychology including the scope of psychology; biological foundations and the brain; sensation; perception; motivation; personality; learning and memory; emotion; states of consciousness; personality theories; cognition; life-span development; and applied psychology.
297f6c08-f722-432c-94fb-ecee49854016.name: Introduction to Psychology (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examination, and written papers with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

4a00dd20-4b9c-48df-98a8-19f894bb7864.description: The course presents the key areas of biology at an introductory post-secondary level for non-majors. Students are introduced to the chemistry of life, cellular biology, molecular biology, genetics, evolution, and ecology. Topics include basic component of life: the cell; energy and membrane transport in cells; cellular reproduction; DNA: the molecule of life; patterns of inheritance; evolution; biodiversity; ecology; population and community ecology; biotechnology.
4a00dd20-4b9c-48df-98a8-19f894bb7864.name: Introductory Biology (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual and computer based training.

6ccfae33-7fdc-4cd9-a230-d5d39c84cd13.description: The course objective is a continuation of Accounting 1. Topics include corporate accounting and financial statements; long-term liabilities; cash flow and financial statement analysis; managerial accounting; budgeting; and using financial data to make business decisions.
6ccfae33-7fdc-4cd9-a230-d5d39c84cd13.name: Accounting II (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer-based training.

bd9131a6-0856-4c88-8646-ee4455d789cf.description: The course objective is to cover an overview of the anatomical structures and physiology of the human body. The course discusses each body system in terms of the major anatomical structures and functions and explains how each system participates in homeostasis of the body. In addition, the course discusses selected major pathologies, common issues and changes that occur in each body system throughout the lifespan.
bd9131a6-0856-4c88-8646-ee4455d789cf.name: Anatomy & Physiology (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examination, and written papers with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

674db440-f857-46ec-adda-70e2bd62de25.description: The course objective is to build on lessons learned in English Composition I. In addition to reviewing the writing process, students learn research techniques, citation techniques, documentation formats, and critical analysis of written topics.
674db440-f857-46ec-adda-70e2bd62de25.name: English Composition II (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examination, and written papers with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

07c3e685-f564-4b5a-a9ea-259058078204.description: The course objective is to explore the relationship between man and the environment. Students examine the balance between natural resources and the needs of mankind. Students explore the scientific, political, economic, and social implications of environmental science.
07c3e685-f564-4b5a-a9ea-259058078204.name: Environmental Science (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

6f61fa88-5e0c-49d5-8d58-e27faa2d50fb.description: The course objective is to provide an introduction to business accounting. Topics include accounting concepts and principles; financial statements; internal control design; accounting and the business environment; recording business transactions; the adjusting process; completing the accounting cycle; merchandising operations; merchandise inventory; accounting information systems; receivables; plant assets and intangibles; current liabilities and payroll; and partnership.
6f61fa88-5e0c-49d5-8d58-e27faa2d50fb.name: Accounting I (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examinations with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer-based training.

d752b189-7386-4511-af15-592935223b1f.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the fundamentals of American government and politics focusing on the historical evolution of government and policies, the major institutions, and the major processes. Course goals include developing an interest in and understanding of today's government, policy development, and politics as well as developing critical thinking and information-literacy skills in the areas of government and politics.
d752b189-7386-4511-af15-592935223b1f.name: American Government (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

39988fd2-03f6-4e6a-b3fd-787afbdf8ab3.description: Students develop a logical, conceptual, and analytical understanding of microeconomic principles. This course introduces foundational economic principles, such as opportunity costs and supply and demand, and explores primary microeconomic principles, including efficiency and fairness in markets, government actions and their impacts, the decisions that consumers and producers make, different market structures from perfect competition to monopoly, and factor markets and income distribution.
39988fd2-03f6-4e6a-b3fd-787afbdf8ab3.name: Microeconomics (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

7305a373-4fad-46a4-8566-b2f301f2416e.description: The course objective is to cover a broad survey of American history from 1865 through the New Millennium. The general course topics include the West; industrial society; urban society and political realignments; Empire and the Progressive Era; Age of Progressivism; the nation at war; modern America; World War II and the Cold War; the 1960s; a crisis in confidence, 1969-1980; the Republican Resurgence, 1980-1992; and the end of the American century.
7305a373-4fad-46a4-8566-b2f301f2416e.name: American History II (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audiovisual materials and computer based training.

a262a249-3b0d-48a6-b610-4c6a124f6d66.description: This course provides fundamental knowledge in biology that helps students understand the natural world. Students develop scientific inquiry skills through exploration of basic biology and chemistry principles, metabolism and energy transformations, cellular and molecular biology, genetics, and evolutionary processes. Topics include essential principles of chemistry for- biology, biochemistry, cellular biology, metabolism and bioenergetics, mendelian and molecular genetics, and biotechnology.
a262a249-3b0d-48a6-b610-4c6a124f6d66.name: Biology I

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual and computer based training.

57e6747e-9c57-450b-9d42-81d51da6f861.description: This course provides an introduction to effective business communication skills, with an emphasis on the use of these skills as a manager. Students examine important elements of successful communication, analyze examples of effective communication, and practice communicating various business messages across a range of mediums, including professional writing, speeches, and presentations.
57e6747e-9c57-450b-9d42-81d51da6f861.name: Business Communication Skills for Managers

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

8f1749c0-fb51-48ae-a24b-c4838006f08d.description: This course provides an overview of essential computer knowledge and skills aimed at beginning to intermediate computer users. The course begins with the basics of using Windows, basic internet literacy, and basic internet searches. Students then step through targeted skills with Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint. Students complete a Capstone Project that requires them to integrate the three Microsoft products to create two workplace deliverables.
8f1749c0-fb51-48ae-a24b-c4838006f08d.name: Computer Apps for Managers

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

d12f47dd-1c13-425b-8440-112871b45c42.description: The course objective is to focus on Human Resource (HR) management skills used by business managers in day-to-day operations. While focusing on the different aspects of HR management and practices, problem solving, and critical thinking skills are applied. The general course topics include an introduction to environmental science; overview of Human Resource (HR) management; training and development; employee compensation and benefits; employee relations; and global HR management.
d12f47dd-1c13-425b-8440-112871b45c42.name: Human Resource Management (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer-based training.

01723fd6-3d40-4c45-a506-73ec0ea2a47d.description: The course objective is to introduce foundational concepts of economic principles, such as opportunity costs, supply, and demand. However, the course focus is to explore primary macroeconomic principles, including measurement, real economy in the long run, money economy in the long run, macroeconomic fluctuations, and policy issues. Students will be presented with real world contemporary examples that apply theory to practice, demonstrating the relevance of macroeconomic thought.
01723fd6-3d40-4c45-a506-73ec0ea2a47d.name: Macroeconomics (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

3deee28f-506c-4d36-8e3a-5a694e4f2889.description: The course introduces students to management philosophies in today's changing world. It includes globalization, ethics, diversity, customer service, and innovation from a managerial perspective. Topics include social responsibility and managerial ethics; decision making; strategic management and planning; organizational structure and communications; human resource management; motivating and leading others; controlling organizational performance; and operations management.
3deee28f-506c-4d36-8e3a-5a694e4f2889.name: Principles of Management (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

f9e8ab44-a443-4418-86e5-67eea9270c6a.description: The course objective is to provide students with a view of the principle areas of marketing. It explores the factors influencing how marketing decisions are made, including the impact of marketing decisions on an organization and its customers. Students gain a working knowledge of practical marketing and business vocabulary. Additionally, students analyze today's global, highly competitive marketplace and evaluate how the actions of competitors' influence marketing decisions.
f9e8ab44-a443-4418-86e5-67eea9270c6a.name: Principles of Marketing (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual and computer based training.

ee334175-b2eb-4fbc-9ecd-6ba565049c6d.description: This is an introductory course to the basic structures of the Spanish language with a cultural approach. Students review and use grammar, pronunciations of the sound system, and high-frequency language elements, such as verbs and phrases. The course activities emphasize practice with listening, speaking, and writing skills. Topics include nouns, adjectives, and articles and their agreement; formal and informal contexts; vocabulary; regular asking questions; and everyday topics.
ee334175-b2eb-4fbc-9ecd-6ba565049c6d.name: Spanish I

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual and computer based training.

75d888a0-0614-4be0-b905-e667985c2bfc.description: The course provides students with an overview of business in a global society serving as an introduction to business terminology, concepts, environments, systems, strategies, and current issues. Topics include the business ethics and social responsibility; new ventures; business enterprise; managing employees; marketing; product pricing, distribution, and promotion; productivity and quality; information systems; communication; accounting; banking and finance; and risk management.
75d888a0-0614-4be0-b905-e667985c2bfc.name: Introduction to Business (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based learning.

f2e2ee66-f747-4468-8b8a-1e596ae583fa.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the criminal justice system and its three main components: law enforcement, the courts, and corrections. It reviews what constitutes a criminal offense, how crime is measured, and theories of crime causation. This course also looks at issues and challenges facing today's criminal justice system and examines possible future directions.
f2e2ee66-f747-4468-8b8a-1e596ae583fa.name: Introduction to Criminal Justice (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is computer based training.

15c5e2da-ec43-445b-b7af-f9bc3177024d.description: The course explores sociological processes that underlie everyday life, focusing on globalization, cultural diversity, critical thinking, new technology and the growing influence of mass media. Topics include sociology; culture; socialization; deviance and social control; global stratification and racial discrimination; gender and age; social class and decision making; politics and economics; marriage and family; education and religion; population and urbanization; and social change.
15c5e2da-ec43-445b-b7af-f9bc3177024d.name: Introduction to Sociology (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, examination, and presentations with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials, computer based training, and practical exercises.

49d3e91a-1161-486e-b9ab-0c13607e8077.description: This survey course focuses on developing math literacy and problem-solving skills. Emphasis is placed on the applicability of mathematics to real-world situations. Topics include problem solving, voting theory, graph theory, growth models, consumer mathematics, statistical methods, probability, set theory and logic, and counting systems.
49d3e91a-1161-486e-b9ab-0c13607e8077.name: Math for Liberal Arts

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

069e4a1a-b047-4e12-9bc2-6084e18d3a82.description: The course covers a broad survey of business law with respect to torts, crimes, intellectual property, contracts, negotiable instruments, agency, employment, and forms of business organization. Students explore the relationship between business and the law with respect to ethics and social responsibility, government regulation, property, and international trade. Students gain a working knowledge of practical rules of law as well as legal solutions for business- related issues.
069e4a1a-b047-4e12-9bc2-6084e18d3a82.name: Business Law (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

6a6e540b-1f26-419b-9f14-0926e05cc5e8.description: The course objective is to provide a basic math review; business statistics; profit calculations; payroll; banking; insurance; taxes; and other business topics including whole numbers, fractions and decimals; percentages and statistics; trade and cash discounts, markup, and markdown; interest, discount, credit, and value; annuities, sinking funds, stocks, and bonds; mortgages; depreciation; inventory financial statements.
6a6e540b-1f26-419b-9f14-0926e05cc5e8.name: Business Math (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials, computer based training, and practical exercises.

44850dd5-f404-4a3d-aff0-98fbd28b4776.description: The course objective is to teach students the fundamentals of criminal investigation by examining the processes involved in identifying and arresting criminal suspects, identifying the types of crimes and offenses, and preparing for court. Topics include crime scene and crime lab; intelligence and surveillance; search and seizure and making the arrest; interviews, interrogations, and informants; multiple types of offenses; and preparation for court.
44850dd5-f404-4a3d-aff0-98fbd28b4776.name: Criminal Investigation (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

ddc0d86b-889e-4443-859f-2821db30e718.description: The course objective is to look at the ethical dilemmas and professional problems faced by criminal justice personnel. Students review various ethical perspectives and discuss the practical applicability of ethical ideals. Topics include recognizing ethical decisions; virtue ethics; formalism; utilitarianism; crime and law; ethical theories, crime, and law; courts adjudication; punishment and corrections; liability; and being ethical when no one is looking.
ddc0d86b-889e-4443-859f-2821db30e718.name: Criminal Justice Ethics (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

610d9c79-3061-4487-b6f9-a51c1fa12793.description: The course objective is to focus on the constitutional rights of criminal defendants as interpreted by the U.S. Supreme Court. Students discuss Supreme Court decisions and identify their significance for the justice system.
610d9c79-3061-4487-b6f9-a51c1fa12793.name: Criminal Procedure (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

f41dc88e-24b4-4c86-b208-a72c65e8ff21.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the study of crime and criminal behavior as well as to theories of crime causation. It reviews different types of crime and examines crime control policy. Topics include patterns of crime; theories of criminology; biological & psychological theories of criminal behavior; social structure and process; social development and conflict; crimes against perssons & property; drug abuse and crime; other types of crime; and social policy and the future.
f41dc88e-24b4-4c86-b208-a72c65e8ff21.name: Criminology (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

4ac32436-9925-4b92-91a8-0475e17d5541.description: The course objective is to introduce students to the challenges and opportunities of entrepreneurship. It includes sound academic theory, success stories, case studies, and exercises in critical thinking to help students develop the understanding, skills, and plans needed to start a successful new business.
4ac32436-9925-4b92-91a8-0475e17d5541.name: Entrepreneurship (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

3420f85b-2fc2-4142-9ed8-aba487793997.description: The course objective is to enhance your personal and professional learning agenda and welcome the challenges of supervision. In this course, you will learn about the roles and responsibilities of supervisors. The course builds from a foundation of fundamental skills through a pyramid of understanding the expanded scope of responsibilities for first-time, first-line supervisors through the chairman of the board in private, service, or public organizations.
3420f85b-2fc2-4142-9ed8-aba487793997.name: Supervision (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer-based training.

0c4ab30f-8667-4f12-849a-7c6ca98baa4a.description: The course objective is to provide students with an overview of the criminal justice system and its processes. It examines the courtroom work group, the trial process, challenges to the process, and the juvenile court system. Topics include introduction to the courts; crimes and defenses; history of the courts; prosecution and defense; judges; jurors and other participants; case attrition and bail; plea bargains; jury trials; court-ordered punishment; sentencing; and appeals and juvenile courts.
0c4ab30f-8667-4f12-849a-7c6ca98baa4a.name: Criminal Courts (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

a1cc8fa1-dd23-4d5f-b8c5-e5fc14700b85.description: This course is a survey of the field of human resources management and encourages students to think critically about the organizational, legal, and social implications of managing employees. Students examine specific strategies to plan for, recruit, compensate, develop, and engage a company’s workforce.
a1cc8fa1-dd23-4d5f-b8c5-e5fc14700b85.name: Human Resources Management

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, written papers, and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual and computer based training.

bc2f4bf5-8769-408e-8be4-fd17c16ef2f9.description: The course objective is to provide an overview of the field of corrections. It reviews prisons and jails, correctional policies, agencies, prison life, and challenges facing corrections. The general course topics include crime and corrections; correctional options; prisons; parole and rehabilitation; adult offenders; special offenders; prison management; prison life; prison employees; legal issues in corrections; correctional challenges; and the future of corrections.
bc2f4bf5-8769-408e-8be4-fd17c16ef2f9.name: Introduction to Corrections (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is computer based learning.

3bd7cd6b-2182-4f94-9f58-9bf81538cba7.description: The course provides an introduction to the historical, theoretical, and developmental foundations for educating young children, with an emphasis on creating inclusive environments and curricula that are responsive to the needs of diverse children and their families. Topics include history and theories of ECE; current issues; research & policy; child development; effective teaching; special needs and diversity; curriculum standards; health & safety; partnerships; assessment; and professionalism.
3bd7cd6b-2182-4f94-9f58-9bf81538cba7.name: Introduction to Early Childhood Education (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes, examination, and written papers with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based learning.

3c5ef0f6-f6a9-407a-8531-10562ca8e9b8.description: The course objective is to provide students with a foundational knowledge of financial management. The course covers key language and terminology; time-value of money; financial markets and securities; financial statements; financial analysis; risk and return; valuation of stocks and bonds; capital budgeting and valuation; cost of capital and capital structure; working capital management; dividend policy; and international finance.
3c5ef0f6-f6a9-407a-8531-10562ca8e9b8.name: Introduction to Finance (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer-based training.

64d003a3-f675-489b-996b-2c5954346eee.description: The course provides students an overview of the police and their mission. It examines the evolution of policing as well as methods, issues, and challenges to present-day policing. The course also looks at technology in the service of law enforcement and explores the future of policing.
64d003a3-f675-489b-996b-2c5954346eee.name: Introduction to Policing (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with the minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

71db2326-c769-4ea5-b1b9-ed04bb67d8de.description: The course objective is to explore policing techniques and tactics used to combat and prevent crime. Emphasis is placed on the knowledge and working skills involved in the art of interviewing and interrogating witnesses and suspects, and the relevant legal parameters that must be followed during field procedures.
71db2326-c769-4ea5-b1b9-ed04bb67d8de.name: Policing Techniques (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

1db11acc-59ee-420e-a4ab-2a9771909a10.description: The course provides students with an historical understanding of criminal law, overview of general legal principles, including possible defenses, and an awareness of the fundamental nature of law. Topics include purposes and sources of criminal law; criminal liability; insanity; personal crime; property and computer crimes; crimes against public order and the government; crimes against public decency and morality; victims and the law; and punishment and sentencing.
1db11acc-59ee-420e-a4ab-2a9771909a10.name: Criminal Law (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

1fa720a3-378a-4e61-adb8-2a7aa3650251.description: The course objective is for students to develop a logical, conceptual, and analytical understanding of economic principles and to deal with problems associated with the allocation of resources; decisions made by consumers; production by firms; pricing in various market conditions; government actions in markets; measuring aggregate output; economic growth; employment and unemployment; money and banking; and fiscal and monetary policies intended to achieve economic goals.
1fa720a3-378a-4e61-adb8-2a7aa3650251.name: Introduction to Economics

alignments.name: Regional Accreditation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

ff2d7e5e-4316-4214-a715-620feb56b9ae.description: The course objective is to provide an overview of American juvenile justice in terms of both system and practice. It examines the juvenile offender, causes of juvenile crime, the juvenile court system, and juveniles in the adult court system. This course also looks at the institutionalization, rehabilitation, and treatment of juveniles, and the future of juvenile justice in America.
ff2d7e5e-4316-4214-a715-620feb56b9ae.name: Juvenile Justice (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The method of instruction is audio visual materials and computer based training.

8a715048-20eb-43fe-8a50-17a2e8e0664d.description: The course objective is to cover medical terminology, symbols and abbreviations, and the application of this new language in the field of health care. While terms are covered as they relate to body structure and function, the main focus is on medical vocabulary and being able to construct terms using word parts such as roots, suffixes, and prefixes.
8a715048-20eb-43fe-8a50-17a2e8e0664d.name: Medical Terminology

alignments.name: Regional Accrediation
alignments.description: This course is offered in collaboration with Pearson's regionally accredited college and university partners and meets higher education accreditation requirements.

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include audio visual materials and computer based training.

ea327cac-f880-4b5c-a099-2a7a7ba00a9c.description: The course focuses on adult and juvenile probation, parole, and related institutions. Topics include probation and parole; juvenile court and juvenile justice; juvenile institutions and aftercare; history; sentencing and presentence investigation (PSI); American prisons and community-based corrections; parole and the indeterminate sentence; parole administration and services; rehabilitation; probation and parole officers; probation and parole supervision; and special problems and programs.
ea327cac-f880-4b5c-a099-2a7a7ba00a9c.name: Probation and Parole (P20.23)

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examination with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
